Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Cardiac Index-Guided Therapy in Major Abdominal Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to either cardiac index-guided therapy or routine care.

Participants.evidence: Conducted in three German and two Spanish centres, this multicentre randomised controlled trial enrolled 380 high-risk patients.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention involved maintaining a cardiac index at which pulse pressure variation was <12% using intravenous fluids and dobutamine.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to determine if maintaining an optimised postinduction cardiac index during and for the first 8 hours after surgery reduces postoperative complications in high-risk patients undergoing elective major open abdominal surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of a composite of moderate or severe complications within 28 days post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Patients were blinded to group allocation, but clinicians and outcome assessors were not.

Number_Randomised.evidence: this multicentre randomised controlled trial enrolled 380 high-risk patients.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of the 380 enrolled, 318 were analysed (152 in the intervention group and 166 in the control group) using a modified intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The composite primary outcome occurred in 55% of the intervention group and 46% of the control group (odds ratio: 1.87, 95% CI: 1.03–3.39, P = 0.038).

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported.

Funding.evidence: Funding: Pulsion Medical Systems, Germany, and institutional and departmental sources.
